pr_title: Removed not-null assertions, as our eslint config no longer allows them.

timeline.message:
Removed not-null assertions, as our eslint config no longer allows them.

Another change that has to be made was removing a string type assertion, as eslint was also erroring on that

timeline.bodyText:
event should automatically have a type here:

  
    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                    onChange={(event: any) =>
          
          
            
                    onChange={(event) =>
timeline.author: ChristianMurphy
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -248,8 +249,8 @@ export const DateRangeSelector = ({
         value={dateRangeToDateOptionConverter(stateDateRange)}
         id="date_range_selector"
         labelId="date_range_selector_label"
-        onChange={(event) =>
-          handleQuickDateOptionChange(event.target.value as string)
+        onChange={(event: any) =>

replies.bodyText:
Putting any as the type was to get around event.target.value now being an Unknown type.
ESLint complains aboutthe string assertion 'This assertion is unnecessary since it does not change the type of the expression'
But i'm open to other ways to get around this. Since using any feels like a bit of a hack
replies.author: mrblippy

replies.bodyText:
try switching target to currentTarget.
target bubbles events up, if there were another input inside the input it would catch that, so it's type is dynamic and unknown.
currentTarget refers to the element which the listener is attached to, so it can be statically typed.
replies.author: ChristianMurphy

replies.bodyText: That seems to work nicely, thank you for your suggestion  @ChristianMurphy 👍 👍
replies.author: mrblippy

timeline.message: Use event.currentTarget instead of event.target, to keep ESLint happy
